newsitem.title: USA: Dollar ends lower ahead of Rubin trip, jobs data.
newsitem.headline: Dollar ends lower ahead of Rubin trip, jobs data.

text.p: The dollar fell against the mark and the yen on Thursday after the release of strong German economic data and a report from the International Monetary Fund that said the yen had room to rise.
Nervousness preceding the release of key U.S. employment data and meetings between U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and top Japanese government officials on Friday also weighed on the dollar.

"The market is very afraid about whether Rubin will say more about trade in Japan and we're also cautious ahead of the non-farm payrolls number on Friday," said Bob Near, a vice president on the corporate foreign exchange desk at Bank of New York.

The currency market has been preoccupied for much of the week with U.S. warnings about Japan's hefty trade surplus with the United States, which is viewed by many as a direct result of the dollar's two-year rise against the yen.
On Thursday, Japanese Ministry of Finance officials tried to nip any incipient trade tensions in the bud, saying they did not expect the Japanese trade surplus to expand drastically.
But more harsh trade rhetoric from Secretary Rubin on Friday would suggest that the Clinton administration's tolerance for a strong dollar is limited.
The dollar ended the day at 122.59 yen, down from 123.24 yen Wednesday. Against the mark, the dollar drifted down to 1.6695 from 1.6755.
Strong German industrial output figures for February were behind the mark's strong performance Thursday.
German industrial production, driven by manufacturing strength and a seasonal rebound in construction, rose 1.9 percent in February over January and by 7.1 percent over February of 1996.
"The sharp reversal of fortune for the dollar from Wednesday to Thursday is partially based on the good economic news out of Germany," said Bob Savage, chief dealer at Lehman Brothers.
The dollar's weakness against the yen emerged after release of an International Monetary Fund paper scheduled to be presented at a meeting of Asia-Pacific finance officials over the weekend.
The report said that the yen's depreciation since reaching post-World War II highs in early 1995 had corrected misalignments, but also noted that some of the yen's fall could be reversed.
"The IMF comments gave the market an excuse to sell the dollar against the yen," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at Bank Leumi Trust Co. of New York.
Overall, however, Waxman said that trading was fairly subdued ahead of Friday's March jobs report, which is expected to clarify prospects for another interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve.
In other trade Thursday, the dollar pushed up to its highest level in two years against the Canadian dollar, before ending at C$1.3926 against C$1.3858 on Wednesday.
The dollar settled at 1.4345 Swiss francs, down from 1.4420, while the British pound rose modestly to $1.6452 from $1.6440 on Wednesday.
